keyTakeAways: Colombia has recalled its ambassador to the United States, Daniel García-Peña, for consultations, marking a significant diplomatic escalation.
The recall comes amid allegations that the U.S. supported a plot to remove President Gustavo Petro from power, which Colombia claims was baseless.
U.S. President Donald Trump accused Petro of being a 'drug leader' and threatened to cut subsidies and raise tariffs on Colombian exports.

The United States has launched military operations in the Caribbean, attacking seven vessels suspected of drug trafficking, resulting in 30 deaths and accusations from Colombia that some victims were Colombian citizens.
Colombia accused the U.S. of 'murder' in relation to the attacks, claiming some of the victims were Colombian nationals, and a Colombian citizen on the latest vessel was returned alive.
This is the second time in 2025 that the Colombian ambassador to Washington has been recalled, highlighting recurring diplomatic tensions over drug trade and sovereignty concerns.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Colombia has recalled its ambassador to the United States, Daniel García-Peña, for consultations, in response to U.S. military actions targeting suspected drug-smuggling vessels in the Caribbean and accusations from President Gustavo Petro that the United States supported a plot to remove him from power. The move follows a previous diplomatic exchange in July, when the U.S. recalled its ambassador to Bogotá. Tensions escalated after President Donald Trump accused Petro of being a 'drug leader' and threatened to cut subsidies and raise tariffs on Colombian exports. Seven vessels have been attacked, resulting in 30 deaths, with Colombia claiming some victims were Colombian nationals and accusing the U.S. of 'murder'. A Colombian citizen aboard the latest vessel was returned alive, further intensifying the conflict over sovereignty, drug trafficking, and economic retaliation.
title: Colombian ambassador to US recalled to Bogotá for consultations, embassy says
